quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Forces on Inclined Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 3: Inclined Planes & Friction (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A 5.0 kg block slides down a frictionless inclined plane that makes a $30^\circ$ angle with the horizontal. What is the block's acceleration down the incline?
questions.explanation: On a frictionless incline, acceleration $a = g \sin\theta = 9.8 \times \sin30^\circ = 9.8 \times 0.5 = 4.9 \ \text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A 12 kg crate is placed on a ramp inclined at $25^\circ$. The coefficient of static friction is $\mu_s = 0.40$. Will the crate begin to slide down the ramp?
options: No, because friction can hold it
No, because the angle is too shallow
questions.explanation: Calculate: $mg\sin\theta = 12 \times 9.8 \times \sin25^\circ \approx 49.7 \ \text{N}$. Max static friction $= \mu_s mg\cos\theta = 0.40 \times 117.6 \times \cos25^\circ \approx 42.6 \ \text{N}$. Since $49.7 > 42.6$, the crate will slide.

questions.question: A skier with total mass 65 kg descends a $20^\circ$ slope. The coefficient of kinetic friction between skis and snow is $\mu_k = 0.10$. What is the skier's acceleration down the slope?
A 3.0 kg block is pushed up a $40^\circ$ incline with a force of 50 N parallel to the incline. $\mu_k = 0.30$. What is the block's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Downhill component: $mg\sin40^\circ \approx 18.90 \ \text{N}$. Normal: $N = mg\cos40^\circ \approx 22.52 \ \text{N}$. Friction: $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.30 \times 22.52 \approx 6.76 \ \text{N}$ (downhill, opposes motion). Net force uphill: $50 - 18.90 - 6.76 = 24.34 \ \text{N}$. $a = 24.34/3.0 \approx 8.12 \ \text{m/s}^2$ up.

questions.question: A 15 kg box is placed on a ramp inclined at $15^\circ$. $\mu_s = 0.35$. What minimum force parallel to the incline is needed to prevent the box from sliding down?
questions.explanation: Downhill component: $mg\sin15^\circ \approx 38.04 \ \text{N}$. Max static friction: $\mu_s mg\cos15^\circ \approx 49.70 \ \text{N}$. Since max friction $>$ downhill force, friction alone holds it, so no additional force needed.

questions.question: A 2.0 kg block is at rest on a $35^\circ$ incline. $\mu_s = 0.45$. Does it remain at rest? If not, what is its acceleration (using $\mu_k = \mu_s$)?
questions.explanation: Downhill: $mg\sin35^\circ \approx 11.24 \ \text{N}$. Max static friction: $\mu_s mg\cos35^\circ \approx 7.23 \ \text{N}$. Since $11.24 > 7.23$, it slides. $a = g(\sin\theta - \mu_k \cos\theta) = 9.8(0.5736 - 0.45 \times 0.8192) \approx 2.01 \ \text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A 10 kg block slides up a $25^\circ$ incline with initial speed $8.0 \ \text{m/s}$. $\mu_k = 0.25$. How far up the incline does it travel before stopping?
questions.explanation: Deceleration $a = g(\sin\theta + \mu_k \cos\theta) = 9.8(0.4226 + 0.25 \times 0.9063) \approx 6.36 \ \text{m/s}^2$ down incline. Using $v_f^2 = v_0^2 + 2ad$: $0 = 8.0^2 + 2(-6.36)d \rightarrow d \approx 5.03 \ \text{m}$.

questions.question: A force of 60 N parallel to the incline pushes an 8.0 kg block up a $30^\circ$ incline. $\mu_k = 0.20$. What is the block's acceleration?
questions.explanation: Downhill: $mg\sin30^\circ = 39.2 \ \text{N}$. Normal: $N = mg\cos30^\circ \approx 67.90 \ \text{N}$. Friction: $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.20 \times 67.90 \approx 13.58 \ \text{N}$ (downhill). Net uphill: $60 - 39.2 - 13.58 = 7.22 \ \text{N}$. $a = 7.22/8.0 \approx 0.90 \ \text{m/s}^2$ up.

questions.question: A 4.0 kg block on a $20^\circ$ incline is pushed with a 25 N horizontal force (not parallel to incline). $\mu_k = 0.15$. Find the acceleration along the incline.
questions.explanation: Force components: parallel to incline $= 25 \cos20^\circ \approx 23.49 \ \text{N}$ up, perpendicular $= 25 \sin20^\circ \approx 8.55 \ \text{N}$ into incline. Normal $N = mg\cos20^\circ + 8.55 \approx 45.39 \ \text{N}$. Friction $f_k = 0.15 \times 45.39 \approx 6.81 \ \text{N}$ down incline. Downhill weight component: $mg\sin20^\circ \approx 13.41 \ \text{N}$. Net uphill: $23.49 - 13.41 - 6.81 = 3.27 \ \text{N}$. $a = 3.27/4.0 \approx 0.82 \ \text{m/s}^2$ up.

questions.question: A 6.0 kg block slides down a $40^\circ$ incline with $\mu_k = 0.25$. What is its acceleration?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered forces on inclined surfaces with friction.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of incline physics and friction calculations.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice resolving forces into components on inclines.
scoreMessages.0: Review force components, normal force, and friction on inclines.
